abstract: Crash of AirAsia Flight 8501 into Java Sea has raised fears that Indonesia's aviation infrastructure, already considered safety deficient, is struggling to handle increasing popularity of air travel; investigators are still looking for both victims' bodies and reasons for crash.
lead_paragraph: There are renewed concerns that Indonesia cannot keep up with the growing popularity of air travel as incomes rise and low-cost carriers multiply.

byline.contributor: Thomas Fuller reported from Jakarta, and Keith Bradsher from Sydney, Australia. Reporting was contributed by Tom McCawley from Surabaya, Indonesia; Austin Ramzy from Hong Kong; Nicola Clark from Paris; and Poypiti Amatatham from Bangkok.
byline.original: By THOMAS FULLER and KEITH BRADSHER

snippet: There are renewed concerns that Indonesia cannot keep up with the growing popularity of air travel as incomes rise and low-cost carriers multiply.

headline.main: Crash of AirAsia Flight 8501 Spotlights Indonesia’s Poor Air Safety Record
headline.print_headline: Crash Renewing Scrutiny of Indonesia’s Lax Airlines
